The company claims its new approach offers control over privacy settings while continuing to support cookies for those who want them. Google's new plan is similar to Apple's App Tracking Transparency (ATT) feature, which requires explicit user permission for advertising tracking. Google's Privacy Sandbox APIs will still be available, and the company intends to offer additional privacy controls, including IP Protection in Chrome's Incognito mode.  Despite Google's claims of user choice, experts argue that third-party cookies are essentially dead, and advertisers are already seeking alternative monetization strategies.  Google's business model heavily relies on advertising, and the company has a vast amount of user data from multiple services. While privacy-conscious users may opt out of cookies, Google is prepared for a scenario where a significant portion of its user base continues to use them, as seen with Apple's ATT.  Google is advising developers to act as if they don't have cookies, suggesting a shift away from reliance on the technology. Experts emphasize the importance of ensuring that opting out of cookies is straightforward and doesn't negatively impact user functionality or workflow.
headline: Google’s U-Turn on Third-Party Cookies Means for Chrome Privacy
summary: Google has reversed its decision to abolish third-party cookies in Chrome, drawing criticism from privacy advocates. The company argues its new approach offers user control over privacy settings, but experts believe the tracking technology is essentially dead.

description: The FBI is still unable to access the encrypted phone of indicted NYC Mayor Eric Adams, a significant development in the corruption case against him. Prosecutors revealed in court that the FBI has been unable to crack the encryption on Adams' personal phone, which was seized nearly a year ago. Adams claims he changed the passcode and subsequently forgot it, leaving the FBI in a similar situation to their investigation into the San Bernardino mass shooting, where a cybersecurity firm eventually unlocked the shooter's iPhone.  In another privacy-related story, a group of Harvard students have demonstrated the ease with which face recognition technology can be integrated into Meta's Ray-Ban Meta smart glasses. The project, known as I-XRAY, uses the Pimeyes service to allow wearers to identify individuals and access their personal information.  Meta has also confirmed that it will use data from users' smart glasses to train its AI products.  Meanwhile, the US Justice Department, alongside Microsoft and the NGO Information Sharing and Analysis Center, seized control of over 100 web domains used by Russian hackers working for the FSB. These domains were exploited in phishing campaigns by the Star Blizzard group, which has targeted journalists, think tanks, and NGOs. The domain seizures are intended to disrupt Russian hacking operations and mitigate foreign interference in the upcoming US election.
headline: The FBI Still Hasn’t Cracked NYC Mayor Eric Adams’ Phone
summary: The FBI is unable to access the encrypted phone of indicted NYC Mayor Eric Adams, posing a challenge in the corruption case against him. Meanwhile, a Harvard project demonstrates the potential privacy risks of face recognition integrated into smart glasses, and the US seizes domains used by Russian hackers.

description: License plate-scanning cameras, initially designed for traffic enforcement, are now capturing images of political lawn signs outside private homes, individuals wearing T-shirts with text, and vehicles displaying pro-abortion bumper stickers. Data obtained by WIRED shows that DRN Data, a license-plate-recognition (LPR) company owned by Motorola Solutions, is collecting this information and storing it in searchable databases. Searches for common phrases or names, such as those of politicians, return photographs where the search term is present, even if it is not displayed on license plates. This raises concerns about the privacy of individuals and their political views.
headline: License Plate Readers Are Creating a US-Wide Database of More Than Just Cars
summary: AI-powered cameras mounted on cars and trucks are capturing images of political lawn signs, individuals wearing T-shirts with text, and vehicles displaying pro-abortion bumper stickers. The data is stored in searchable databases that reveal Americans’ political leanings and more.

description: US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) has signed a $2 million contract with Israeli commercial spyware vendor Paragon Solutions. The contract covers a “fully configured proprietary solution including license, hardware, warranty, maintenance and training”. Paragon’s contract comes amid a comprehensive effort by the US government to reshape the commercial spyware market. Measures have included placing spyware vendors like NSO Group and Intellexa on the so-called Entity List to prevent any US companies from doing business with them; enacting a visa restriction policy against multiple individuals “who have been involved in the development and sale of commercial spyware or who are immediate family members of those involved,” and imposing consecutive rounds of sanctions against spyware vendors.
headline: ICE Signs $2 Million Contract With Spyware Maker Paragon Solutions
summary: US Immigration and Customs Enforcement has signed a $2 million contract with Israeli spyware vendor Paragon Solutions. The contract comes amid a comprehensive effort by the US government to reshape the commercial spyware market.

description: Apple has launched a new standalone password manager app, Passwords, in iOS 18. The app is automatically included with iOS 18 and is a public-facing evolution of its Keychain and password-saving capabilities. Passwords uses end-to-end encryption to save your details, meaning nobody, not even Apple, knows what you have saved. Within the app, you can search for login details to your entries and set up groups to share passwords with other people. The app is locked using Face ID.
headline: Apple’s New Passwords App May Solve Your Login Nightmares
summary: Apple is launching its first stand-alone password manager app in iOS 18. The new Passwords app is automatically included with iOS 18, and is a public-facing evolution of its Keychain and password-saving capabilities.

description: Apple announced its late but major move into AI at the Worldwide Developers Conference on June 10 with “Apple Intelligence,” confirming months-long rumors that it would partner with OpenAI to bring ChatGPT to iPhones. Elon Musk, one of the cofounders of OpenAI, was quick to respond on X, branding ChatGPT-powered Apple AI tools “creepy spyware” and an “unacceptable security violation.” “If Apple integrates OpenAI at the OS level, then Apple devices will be banned at my companies,” Musk wrote. However, Apple says Apple Intelligence offers a new way of protecting people’s data, with the firm working out which core tasks can be processed on the device. Apple has also developed a cloud-based system called Private Cloud Compute (PCC) running on its own silicon servers, which the company says is an innovative new way to protect privacy in the nascent AI age. Apple’s senior vice president of software engineering Craig Federighi calls its strategy “a brand-new standard for privacy in AI.” Experts are debating whether Apple’s claims are valid and how the iPhone maker’s strategy compares to “hybrid AI” offerings available on devices including Samsung’s Galaxy range. With PCC, Apple has designed “a new end-to-end AI architecture” and “a private cloud enclave extension of a user's iPhone,” allowing more control over data, says Zak Doffman, CEO of Digital Barriers, which specializes in real-time surveillance video storage and analysis. Apple has put together a “pretty impressive privacy system” for its AI, says Bruce Schneier, chief of security architecture at Inrupt.  “Hybrid AI” used on Samsung Galaxy devices running Google Android and Google’s Nano range sees some AI processes handled locally, leveraging cloud when necessary to enable more advanced capabilities. Google and its hardware partners argue privacy and security are a major focus of the Android AI approach. VP Justin Choi, head of the security team, mobile eXperience business at Samsung Electronics, says its hybrid AI offers users “control over their data and uncompromising privacy.” Samsung “clearly indicates” which AI functions run on the device with its Galaxy AI symbol, and the smartphone maker adds a watermark to show when content has used generative AI. The firm has also introduced a new security and privacy option called Advanced Intelligence settings to give users the choice to disable cloud-based AI capabilities. Google says it “has a long history of protecting user data privacy,” adding that this applies to its AI features powered on-device and in the cloud. “We utilize on-device models, where data never leaves the phone, for sensitive cases such as screening phone calls,” Suzanne Frey, vice president of product trust at Google, tells WIRED. Apple Intelligence will be integrated into its soon-to-launch iOS 18 software update alongside ChatGPT, with the full suite of features coming to the iPhone 16 this fall.
headline: Apple Intelligence Privacy vs. Android Hybrid AI:  A Battle for User Data
summary: Apple announced its new AI system, Apple Intelligence, which will be integrated with ChatGPT on iPhones. Samsung and Google offer a hybrid AI approach, processing some tasks locally and others in the cloud.  Experts debate the security and privacy implications of each approach.

description: Business email compromise (BEC) scams are a big deal. The con artists behind this criminal enterprise will cold-email you, pretending to be someone you work with, in order to gain access to money or information. You might get an email that appears to be from your company’s CEO asking you to quickly do something like buy gift cards, or you might get an email that looks like it's from an employee at your company asking you to change their direct deposit information. The scam itself can take a lot of forms, but the end goal is to somehow siphon money away from you or the business you work for. When I asked two cybersecurity experts about BEC fraud, I expected them to lead with technical advice. Both started with emotions. This makes sense: While such fraud happens on computers, it is at its heart about psychological manipulation. So spotting an email compromise scam requires getting in touch with how you're feeling. If an email elicits an emotional response, take a step back and reread it when you're more calm, says Ronnie Tokazowski, a security researcher who has been working to educate people about email scams for over a decade. The stress the scam induces is what keeps you from questioning the premise. “People who get pulled into these types of scams … their emotions get very deregulated,” he says. That makes you less capable of thinking critically, which is a key part of how such scams work. Selena Larson, a threat researcher at cybersecurity firm Proofpoint, says to slow down, take a deep breath, and think critically. Would this be an email that someone would send me? Is this is a logical thing that I'm being asked to do? You should be particularly skeptical if the person sending the email asks you to keep something quiet. Scammers do things like isolate you from your peers, says Larson.  They come at you from a position of authority and say things like, ‘Please keep this confidential and only between us.’ This type of social engineering makes it so people feel like they have to take an action with some kind of urgency, and that you can't share it with anybody. If you received an email like this, it’s important to pick up the phone and call the number you know to be legitimate, says Larson, adding a caveat. Do not rely on a phone number in the email itself—it will be owned by the threat actor. Any contact information in the email itself is likely compromised, and sometimes cleverly so. Use the phone number you’ve already saved in your phone for the person in question, or look up the phone number on an official website or in an official company directory. This applies even if the number in the email looks correct, because some scammers will go through the trouble of getting a phone number that’s similar to that of the person they’re impersonating, all on the hopes that you’ll call that number instead of the real one. Always check the domains that you’re receiving emails from, says Larson. Sometimes this will be obvious; your CEO likely isn’t emailing you from a Gmail account, for example. Sometimes it will be more subtle—fraudsters have been known to purchase domains that look similar to that of the company they’re attempting to defraud, all in the hopes of appearing legitimate. It’s also worth checking to see if the email signature matches the address the email is coming from. “If you look in the footer, they’ll use the actual domain of the company to make it look legitimate, but that won’t match the email address,” says Larson. Just keep in mind that the difference might be subtle. “Look-alike domains are very common: Someone will do a slight variation, like an ‘l’ instead of an ‘i’, to make it look legitimate.” One way to test that, if you’re suspicious, is to copy and paste the domain half of the address into a browser. If you don’t get a website, you’re probably dealing with a fake.
headline: How to Spot a Business Email Compromise Scam
summary: Business email compromise (BEC) scams often involve criminals posing as a boss or coworker, urging employees to take urgent actions involving money.  BEC scammers often use psychological manipulation and social engineering to convince victims to comply.

description: RCS (Rich Communication Services) is an upgrade on the standard SMS/MMS texting standards that smartphones have been using from the start. It brings better support for all the cool features we’re used to in our messaging apps, like read receipts and images, and it adds some extra security layers too. Yes, it’s a lot like using iMessage from Apple, or using WhatsApp—though it’s not quite that simple. There’s no RCS app you can install, but you can find apps that support the RCS standard, as we’ll explain. RCS is a fundamental standard rather than an app like WhatsApp, Signal, or Telegram. It requires carrier support to work, which is why adoption was slow in the beginning, though RCS now works across most countries and is supported by AT&T, Verizon, and T-Mobile. SMS (Short Message Service) and MMS (Multimedia Messaging Service) weren’t really built for the modern way that we communicate through our phones, and RCS tries to fix that. It adds or improves support for sharing large-resolution images and video, group chatting, read receipts, video calls, and messages that actually go beyond 160 characters. When RCS is supported in your phone’s default texting app, you can add reactions to messages, see when someone else is typing, and drop extra elements like GIFs, stickers, and your current location into conversations—all features you may well be used to and accept as standard in other apps. There are changes and upgrades behind the scenes as well. Whereas SMS/MMS requires a data connection to your cellular network, RCS works over cell networks as well as Wi-Fi. If you don’t have a cell signal for whatever reason but you can find a wireless network, your message can still go through. The standard also brings end-to-end encryption with it. It means that no one else—not even Google or your carrier—can see the conversation that’s taking place, because only the devices involved in the conversation have the keys necessary to decrypt it. End-to-end encryption is a security feature you should look for in any app that handles sensitive information, including communications. It’s a clear upgrade, which is why Google Messages and Samsung Messages now support it—the messaging apps you’ll find on Pixel phones and Galaxy phones, respectively. In November 2023, Apple finally relented and agreed to support RCS on the iPhone in 2024, though this course correction perhaps had more to do with concerns about antitrust procedures than any newfound sense of camaraderie with Google. Now we know that iPhone RCS support is going to arrive in September with iOS 18. This means all of those features we’ve mentioned—from read receipts to message reactions—will work inside the iOS Messages app. However, Android users are still going to show up as green bubbles, as the RCS standard isn’t going to be fully integrated with the iMessage platform that Apple operates. With iOS 18 still in its development stage, there might be changes to come for how RCS is handled on iPhones before the software is rolled out to all compatible devices later in the year. This version of iOS will work on any iPhone models launched in 2018 or later, so most Apple handsets currently in use will get the software and RCS. It’s the same with Samsung Messages: RCS is simply enabled when available. It’s Google Messages for Android that gives you most control over RCS settings, and you can get to them from inside the app by tapping your profile picture (top right), then selecting Messages settings. Choose RCS chats and you’re able to turn features such as read receipts and typing indicators on or off.
headline: A Guide to RCS: Why Apple Is Adopting It and How It Makes Texting Better
summary: RCS (Rich Communication Services) is a messaging standard that offers features like read receipts and video calls, and adds security with end-to-end encryption.  Apple is adopting RCS for iPhones with iOS 18, making it a more unified messaging experience across devices.

description: The US Supreme Court has declined to hear an appeal to a lower court ruling that the US government can seize nearly 70,000 bitcoins from an individual, identified only as “Individual X,” who allegedly stole the funds from the Silk Road dark-web drug market more than a decade ago. The $4.4 billion in crypto is set to be the largest pile of criminal proceeds ever sold off by the US. However, the former IRS agent who seized the record-breaking sum, Tigran Gambaryan, is currently in a Nigerian jail cell, facing charges of money laundering and tax evasion. Gambaryan had left the IRS to work for Binance, the world's largest cryptocurrency exchange, and was detained in Nigeria while negotiating with the government over accusations of similar criminal misconduct by Binance. Despite his vital role in the Silk Road case, Gambaryan has been denied medical care in jail for a worsening herniated disc in his back. Lawmakers and US officials have increasingly appealed to the Nigerian government to release Gambaryan on bail or on medical grounds.
headline: 69,000 Bitcoins Seized by US Treasury, While Agent Who Seized Them Is in Jail
summary: The US government is set to seize 69,370 bitcoins stolen from Silk Road, worth $4.4 billion, but the IRS agent who seized the funds, Tigran Gambaryan, is imprisoned in Nigeria.

description: The US military is increasingly using video game-style controllers to operate advanced weapons systems, such as the Army’s new Maneuver-Short Range Air Defense (M-SHORAD) system, the Air Force’s RADBO truck, and the HELEX laser weapon system. The Freedom of Movement Control Unit (FMCU) handsets, produced by Measurement Systems Inc., offer a familiar and ergonomic design that appeals to the younger generation of potential recruits. The military has long experimented with commercial off-the-shelf console handsets, and the adoption of video game-style controllers reflects a growing trend towards controls that are both familiar and effective for operating complex military systems. These controllers offer tactile feedback and are inherently familiar to the average US service member, who grew up playing video games.
headline: This Video Game Controller Has Become the US Military’s Weapon of Choice
summary: The US military is using video game-style controllers like the FMCU to operate advanced weapons systems, appealing to younger recruits and providing familiar and effective controls.

description: The National Crime Agency (NCA) has released new details about the cybercriminal gang Evil Corp, including its connection to the LockBit ransomware platform and its ties to Russian intelligence. Evil Corp has been operating for over a decade, using malware to compromise bank accounts and steal funds. The group also engaged in ransomware attacks, using platforms like Hades, PhoenixLocker, and LockBit. NCA officials emphasize that Evil Corp is unusual in its direct relationship with multiple Russian intelligence agencies, including the FSB, SVR, and GRU. Before 2019, Evil Corp was allegedly tasked by Russian intelligence with conducting espionage operations and cyberattacks against NATO allies. The NCA reports that the group is organized like a traditional crime syndicate around Maksim Yakubets, its alleged leader, and his family and friends. Despite sanctions and indictments against its members, Evil Corp has continued to evolve and diversify its tactics to maintain its criminal activities.
headline: Notorious Evil Corp Hackers Targeted NATO Allies for Russian Intelligence
summary: The NCA has revealed new information about Evil Corp, a cybercrime group with ties to Russian intelligence, and its use of the LockBit ransomware platform. The group was allegedly tasked by Russia with espionage and cyberattacks against NATO allies.

description: Pig butchering scams, originating in Southeast Asia, have spread to multiple continents, with victims targeted in the Middle East, Eastern Europe, Latin America, and West Africa. The scams involve building intimate relationships with victims and then convincing them to invest in fake cryptocurrency platforms. These operations often involve forced labor and human trafficking, with victims forced to work in scam centers. While Chinese authorities have cracked down on these operations in Southeast Asia, the global spread of pig butchering continues to expand. Experts warn that the scams are becoming more sophisticated and difficult to detect, as criminals are utilizing AI, deepfakes, and malware to further deceive victims.
headline: Pig Butchering Scams Are Going Global
summary: Pig butchering scams, which involve building fake relationships to defraud victims, have expanded globally, particularly in Dubai and Africa.  These scams have been linked to Chinese organized crime and are becoming more sophisticated, leveraging AI and malware to target victims.

description: Generative AI models, such as ChatGPT and Google's Gemini, are trained on massive datasets of information, often scraped from the internet without consent or regard for copyright laws. Many companies are beginning to offer users the ability to opt out of having their data used for AI training. While this may offer some control over personal information, it's important to note that companies often have already scraped data before these opt-out options were implemented, and the process of removing data from training sets can be complicated. Even with opt-outs, companies may still collect and anonymize user data for product improvement purposes.
headline: How to Stop Your Data From Being Used to Train AI
summary: Users can opt out of having their data used to train AI models, but it's a complex process.  Companies may already have scraped data before opt-out options became available, and the process of removing data from training sets can be challenging. Users may need to individually contact companies or adjust website settings.
